DOC.HEAD: State Officials Recommend Independent Inquiry Into Fatal Bridge Accident

DOC.TEXT: A moveable span on a floating bridge opened unexpectedly during a test, thrusting a steel wall in front of rush-hour traffic and causing pileups that killed one woman and injured at least six other people. Department of Transportation officials were at a loss to explain the wreck on the Evergreen Point Floating Bridge across Lake Washington during a test that has been conducted weekly for 18 years without a hitch. The test of electronic circuits doesn't involve moving the span. But during Friday's test, the span rose 4{ feet without warning in about three seconds, creating a wall that three vehicles drove into head-on. Raili Korkka, 44, was killed, police said. Three people were hospitalized in serious but stable condition with a variety of injuries and three others were either treated at the scene or briefly hospitalized, according to police and hospital officials. Motorist Mark Bauty said his car bounced over the lip of the drawspan just as it started to open and he could hear tires screeching and metal crunching behind him. ``The bridge was probably six inches high I guess when I hit it and the car made it over the front end, kept right on going and flew off the back end when the bridge was probably about a foot-and-a-half to two feet high,'' Bauty said. Several cars were left perched on the elevated section of the bridge, some with blown tires and mangled metal from hitting the rising span. No cars went into the water. Operator error has been just about ruled out in the 8:50 a.m. accident, said department spokeswoman Leslie Salisbury, who explained the bridge-opening sequence requires 18 distinct steps. ``When the operator got to the 10th step, for some reason one part of the drawspan opened up,'' she said. Transportation Department crews ran through the procedure three times Friday afternoon, ``and every time we got to that step the drawspan opened,'' Salisbury said. The step should not have involved the drawspan mechanism at all, she said. One expert ``likened it to turning on your windshield wipers and having the radio come on instead,'' Salisbury said. The 25-year-old, 2-mile-long bridge is supported for 7,000 feet on concrete pontoons, making it the world's longest floating bridge. Two steel-grid spans, each 100 feet long, can be raised about 7 feet to make room for boats to pass beneath. Preliminary inspections didn't turn up any damage, but workers plan to inspect the bridge further on Tuesday, and to close the bridge briefly in January for a more detailed look, Salisbury said. The department also has recommended an independent consultant be hired to investigate. The operator of the bridge has been with the department for 10 years and has run the bridge for one year, following two years of training, Salisbury said. The operator was distraught and was treated by medics 45 minutes after the accident, said Daryl Rush, district bridge maintenance superintendent for DOT. Opening the drawspan, which creates a 200-foot opening, is necessary only 30 to 40 times a year because most vessels can pass under elevated portions of the bridge at each end, Rush said. Evergreen Point Bridge, formally known as the Albert D. Rosellini Bridge, carries an average of 100,000 vehicles daily.
